definition.message: Question title must be at least 5 characters
Question body must be at least 10 characters
Assessment title must be at least 3 characters
Time limit must be at least 5 minutes
Passing score must be at least 1%

skill_category.name: JavaScript
skill_category.description: Core JavaScript fundamentals including ES6+, closures, async patterns, and DOM manipulation

skill_category.name: Python
skill_category.description: Python programming including data structures, OOP, and standard library

skill_category.name: SQL & Databases
skill_category.description: SQL queries, database design, indexing, and optimization

skill_category.name: System Design
skill_category.description: Architecture patterns, scalability, distributed systems, and infrastructure

skill_category.name: DevOps
skill_category.description: CI/CD, containers, cloud services, and infrastructure-as-code

question.title: JavaScript Closures
question.explanation: The inner function forms a closure over the 'count' variable. Each call to fn() increments and returns count, so the outputs are 1, 2, 3.

question.title: Promise.all Behavior
question.body: What happens when one of the promises passed to Promise.all() rejects?
question.option_a: It waits for all promises to settle, then returns an array of results and errors
question.option_b: It immediately rejects with the reason of the first promise that rejects
question.option_c: It ignores the rejected promise and resolves with the remaining results
question.explanation: Promise.all() follows a fail-fast pattern — it rejects immediately when any of the input promises rejects, with the reason of the first rejection.

question.title: JavaScript typeof null
question.body: What does typeof null return in JavaScript?
question.explanation: This is a well-known JavaScript quirk. typeof null returns 'object' due to a legacy bug in the original JavaScript implementation that was never fixed for backwards compatibility.

question.title: Event Loop Order
question.explanation: Synchronous code runs first (A, D), then microtasks like Promise callbacks (C), then macrotasks like setTimeout (B).

question.title: Python List Comprehension
question.body:
What does the following expression evaluate to?

[x**2 for x in range(5) if x % 2 == 0]
question.explanation: range(5) produces 0,1,2,3,4. The filter keeps even numbers (0,2,4) and squares them to get [0, 4, 16].

question.title: Python Mutable Default Arguments
question.body:
What happens when you call add_item('apple') twice?

def add_item(item, lst=[]):
    lst.append(item)
    return lst
question.explanation: Mutable default arguments in Python are created once at function definition time and shared across all calls. The list accumulates items between calls.

question.title: Python GIL
question.body: What is the Global Interpreter Lock (GIL) in CPython?
question.option_a: A lock that prevents multiple Python programs from running simultaneously on the same machine
question.option_b: A mutex that allows only one thread to execute Python bytecode at a time
question.option_c: A mechanism to prevent race conditions in multi-process applications
question.option_d: A security feature that restricts access to global variables
question.explanation: The GIL is a mutex in CPython that allows only one thread to execute Python bytecode at a time, even on multi-core systems. This simplifies memory management but limits CPU-bound parallelism in threads.

question.title: SQL JOIN Types
question.body: Which JOIN type returns all rows from the left table and matching rows from the right table, with NULLs for non-matching right-side rows?
question.explanation: A LEFT JOIN (or LEFT OUTER JOIN) returns all rows from the left table regardless of whether there is a match in the right table. Non-matching right-side columns are filled with NULL.

question.title: Database Indexing
question.body: Which index type is most efficient for queries with exact equality conditions on a column with many distinct values?
question.explanation: Hash indexes provide O(1) lookup time for exact equality queries, making them the most efficient choice for high-cardinality equality conditions. However, they do not support range queries.

question.title: SQL Window Functions
question.body: What does ROW_NUMBER() OVER (PARTITION BY department ORDER BY salary DESC) do?
question.option_a: Returns the total number of rows in each department
question.option_b: Assigns a unique sequential number within each department, ordered by salary descending
question.option_c: Returns the rank of each employee, with gaps for ties
question.option_d: Calculates the running total of salaries within each department
question.explanation: ROW_NUMBER() assigns a unique sequential integer starting from 1 within each partition (department), ordered by salary in descending order. Unlike RANK(), it never produces gaps or ties.

question.title: CAP Theorem
question.body: According to the CAP theorem, a distributed system can guarantee at most how many of the three properties (Consistency, Availability, Partition tolerance) simultaneously?
question.option_d: It depends on the database engine
question.explanation: The CAP theorem states that in the presence of a network partition, a distributed system must choose between consistency and availability. You can guarantee at most two of the three properties simultaneously.

question.title: Load Balancing Strategy
question.body: Which load balancing algorithm is best suited for a system where backend servers have significantly different processing capacities?
question.explanation: Weighted Round Robin assigns different weights to servers based on their capacity, sending more requests to more powerful servers. Plain Round Robin and Random treat all servers equally, which would overload weaker servers.

question.title: Docker vs Virtual Machines
question.body: What is the key architectural difference between Docker containers and virtual machines?
question.option_a: Containers include a full guest OS kernel; VMs share the host kernel
question.option_b: Containers share the host OS kernel; VMs include a full guest OS with its own kernel
question.option_c: There is no difference — Docker containers are just lightweight VMs
question.option_d: Containers use hardware virtualization; VMs use OS-level virtualization
question.explanation: Docker containers share the host OS kernel and isolate processes using cgroups and namespaces (OS-level virtualization). VMs run a complete guest OS with its own kernel on top of a hypervisor (hardware virtualization).

question.title: CI/CD Pipeline Stages
question.body: In a typical CI/CD pipeline, what is the correct order of stages?
question.explanation: The standard CI/CD pipeline flows: code review (PR/merge request) → build (compile/bundle) → test (unit, integration, e2e) → deploy (staging, then production).

question.title: Kubernetes Pod vs Container
question.body: What is the relationship between a Pod and a Container in Kubernetes?
question.option_a: A Pod is a container — the terms are interchangeable
question.option_b: A Pod is the smallest deployable unit that can contain one or more containers sharing network and storage
question.option_c: A Container can contain multiple Pods
question.option_d: A Pod is a group of Kubernetes nodes
question.explanation: A Pod is Kubernetes' smallest deployable unit. It wraps one or more containers that share the same network namespace (IP address, ports) and storage volumes, and are always co-located and co-scheduled.

assessment.title: JavaScript Fundamentals Assessment
assessment.description: Evaluate core JavaScript knowledge including closures, promises, event loop, and language quirks. Suitable for mid-level frontend and full-stack developer candidates.

assessment.title: Python Developer Screening
assessment.description: Covers Python fundamentals including list comprehensions, mutable defaults, and concurrency concepts. Designed for backend developer candidates.

assessment.title: Full-Stack Engineer Assessment
assessment.description: Comprehensive assessment covering JavaScript, SQL, system design, and DevOps. For senior full-stack engineer candidates.

assessment.title: DevOps & Cloud Infrastructure
assessment.description: Assessment for DevOps engineer candidates covering containers, CI/CD, Kubernetes, and infrastructure concepts.
